content.raw:
No one is reviewing that ign-math pull request right now, so I don't expect it to land this month.

Would it be better to point to the branch instead of the pull request? Or are you uncomfortable with pointing to unreviewed code?

I thought it would be helpful to have a hands-on utility for converting between representations of rotation. I would have preferred code for an interpreted language, but I think this is a useful alternative.

content.raw:
For consistency, it's odd to see `[x y z]` expanded here, but then RPY not.

Perhaps the wording can be something like:

    The SDFormat specification has the `<pose/>` element which accepts 6 numbers
    in total:
        <pose>x y z roll pitch yaw</pose>
    The elements `x, y, z` define a position vector (in meters), and the elements `roll, pitch, yaw`
    are Euler angles (in radians) that specify the orientation, as shown in the following figure:
        <img/> ...
    {Remove text explaining image; jump straight to concise definition of these specific Euler angles...}

Also, if possible, could we remove the extra prose discussing other Euler angle types, and just jump straight into what these angles are?  
\(If you’d like, I can take a whack at doing a rewording.\)
content.html:
For consistency, it's odd to see [x y z] expanded here, but then RPY not.

Perhaps the wording can be something like:

The SDFormat specification has the `<pose/>` element which accepts 6 numbers
in total:
    <pose>x y z roll pitch yaw</pose>
The elements `x, y, z` define a position vector (in meters), and the elements `roll, pitch, yaw`
are Euler angles (in radians) that specify the orientation, as shown in the following figure:
    <img/> ...
{Remove text explaining image; jump straight to concise definition of these specific Euler angles...}

Also, if possible, could we remove the extra prose discussing other Euler angle types, and just jump straight into what these angles are?
(If you’d like, I can take a whack at doing a rewording.)

content.raw: our image hosting currently looks assumes the `ref` attribute of the `tutorial` element in this manifest.xml is also the folder name where the images are stored. So I could technically put the tutorial.md files wherever I want, but the images would have to be in a different folder
content.html: our image hosting currently looks assumes the ref attribute of the tutorial element in this manifest.xml is also the folder name where the images are stored. So I could technically put the tutorial.md files wherever I want, but the images would have to be in a different folder
